title: Snapdragon 810 delay claims resurface, despite Qualcomm denial | Trusted Reviews
description:
![](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**Talk of the[Snapdragon
810](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/snapdragon-810-features) chipset
[being delayed](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/samsung-galaxy-s6-and-
lg-g4-release-dates-delayed-reports-say) has emerged yet again, just one month
after Qualcomm [flat out refuted the
rumours](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/qualcomm-refutes-claims-of-
snapdragon-810-delays).**

What’s more odd is that LG already revealed its newly announced [LG G Flex
2](https://www.trustedreviews.com/lg-g-flex-2-review) would be carrying the
chip, despite the alleged production issues.

So what’s happened this time? Well it’s the same old story – reports suggest
the Snapdragon 810 is facing serious overheating issues, mirroring last year’s
chatter.

For starters, Korea’s media is rife with rumours that Qualcomm is struggling
to mass-produce the Snapdragon 810, as noted by
[GForGames](http://www.gforgames.com/gadgets/snapdragon-810-issues-mass-
production-postponed-46047/).

What’s more, the [Korea
Times](http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/tech/2015/01/133_171341.html) puts
it down to the fact that overheating is limited performance, as discovered by
Geekbench reports.

A separate [report](http://blogs.barrons.com/asiastocks/2015/01/07/tsmc-jp-
morgan-sees-little-downside-from-qualcomms-snapdragon-
delay/?mod=google_news_blog), courtesy of J.P. Morgan analysts, proposes that
both the Snapdragon 615 and the Snapdragon 810 are suffering overheating
issues, although it’s a more persistent issue on the latter chipset.

**Related:** [Qualcomm Snapdragon 810 gets Cat.9 LTE
support](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/qualcomm-snapdragon-810-gets-
cat-9-lte-support)

  * 

The Snapdragon 810 is an octa-core chip, laid out in ARM’s big.LITTLE
configuration.

This means that four of the cores are Cortex-A53, and the other four are
Cortex-A57.

Apparently, it’s the four Cortex-A57 cores that are giving Qualcomm a
production headache, as they’re overheating when the clock-rate goes north of
1.2-1.4GHz.

Analysts say TSMC – the firm that actually builds Qualcomm’s chips – will be
pushing back the Snapdragon 810 production schedule back by around three
months.

This will give them enough time to redesign some of the chip’s metal layers,
although it could mean there won’t be an abundance of chips until halfway
through 2015.

_TrustedReviews_ spoke to Qualcomm yesterday out at CES. Although the chipset
manufacturer did not discuss potential 810 delays, the company did assure us
the processor would be in ‘multiple’ devices later this quarter and moving
into Q2.

**Related:** [CES 2015: What’s happened at the Las Vegas tech expo so
far?](https://www.trustedreviews.com/hubs/ces-2015)

Qualcomm announced its upcoming flagship Snapdragon 810 chip last year, with
the new tech boating Adreno 430 graphics, 64-bit architecture support,
improved battery life, and 4K video support.

We’re expecting the chip to show up many of this year’s top smartphones,
including the [LG G4](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/lg-g4-release-date-
rumours-news-specs-and-price), the [Sony Xperia
Z4](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/sony-xperia-z4-release-date-rumours-
news-specs-and-price), and the [Samsung Galaxy
S6](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/samsung-galaxy-s6-release-date-
rumours-news-specs-and-price).

Fortunately for Samsung however, it has its own supercharged Exynos chip in
the works that’s been [rumoured to debut in the Galaxy
S6](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/samsung-galaxy-s6-to-land-with-
cat-10-lte-reports-suggest).
